Bivariate Normal Distribution

Nov 6, 2018 • Troy Stribling

The Bivariate Normal Distribution is a frequently used multivariable distribution because it provides a simple model of correlation between random variables. It is derived by application of a linear transformation to a sum of two independent Normal(0, 1)\textbf{Normal}(0,\ 1)Normal(0, 1) random variables. Here a derivation is presented that uses a change of variables on the distribution of the independent variable sum. To provide background a general expression for change of variables of a bivariate integral is discussed. This result is then applied to obtain the Bivariate Normal Distribution. The first and seconds moments and correlation coefficient are next computed followed by derivation of the marginal and conditional distributions which are used in a calculation of the conditional expectation and variance. Finally, the variation in the shape of the distribution as the free parameters are varied is discussed.

Bivariate Change of Variables

First, consider the PDF of a single variable, f(x)f(x)f(x), and the transformation, x=x(y)x=x(y)x=x(y) which is assumed monotonically increasing. The PDF of the transformed variable is given by,

g(y)=f(x(y))dxdy, g(y) = f(x(y)) \frac{dx}{dy}, g(y)=f(x(y))dydx​,

This result follows from performing a change of variables on the CDF,

P(X ≤ x)=∫−∞xf(x)dx=∫−∞yf(x(w))dxdwdy=P(Y ≤ y) \begin{aligned} P(X\ \leq\ x) &= \int_{-\infty}^{x} f(x) dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{y} f(x(w)) \frac{dx}{dw} dy \\ &= P(Y\ \leq\ y) \end{aligned} P(X ≤ x)​=∫−∞x​f(x)dx=∫−∞y​f(x(w))dwdx​dy=P(Y ≤ y)​

where use was made of,

dx=dhdxdy. dx = \frac{dh}{dx} dy. dx=dxdh​dy.

The dh/dxdh/dxdh/dx term stretches or scales dydydy appropriately. In two dimensions a similar thing happens that is slightly more complicated. Consider the PDF of two variables, f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y), with CDF,

P({X,Y}∈A)=∫Af(x,y)dA     (1), P(\{X,Y\} \in A) = \int_{A} f(x, y) dA\ \ \ \ \ (1), P({X,Y}∈A)=∫A​f(x,y)dA     (1),

that defines an integration over a region that computes that probability that XXX and YYY are both in the region AAA. The figure below provides an illustration for a Cartesian Coordinate System where dA=dxdydA=dxdydA=dxdy.

To go further a geometric result relating the Cross Product of two vectors to the area of the parallelogram enclosed by the vectors is needed. This topic is discussed in the following section.

Cross Product as Area

Consider two vectors A\textbf{A}A and B\textbf{B}B separated by an angle θ\thetaθ and rotated by and angle γ\gammaγ as shown in the following figure.

The vector components projected along the x\textbf{x}x and y\textbf{y}y unit vectors is given by,

A=Axx+AyyB=Bxx+Byy, \begin{aligned} \textbf{A} &= A_{x}\textbf{x} + A_{y}\textbf{y} \\ \textbf{B} &= B_{x}\textbf{x} + B_{y}\textbf{y}, \end{aligned} AB​=Ax​x+Ay​y=Bx​x+By​y,​

where,

Ax=∣A∣cosγAy=∣A∣sinγBx=∣B∣cos(γ+θ)By=∣B∣sin(γ+θ)     (2). \begin{aligned} A_{x} &= \mid \textbf{A} \mid \cos{\gamma} \\ A_{y} &= \mid \textbf{A} \mid \sin{\gamma} \\ B_{x} &= \mid \textbf{B} \mid \cos{\left(\gamma + \theta\right)} \\ B_{y} &= \mid \textbf{B} \mid \sin{\left(\gamma + \theta\right)} \\ \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (2). Ax​Ay​Bx​By​​=∣A∣cosγ=∣A∣sinγ=∣B∣cos(γ+θ)=∣B∣sin(γ+θ)​     (2).

The cross product of two vectors is another vector perpendicular both vectors. Here, for the figure above, this direction is perpendicular to the plane of the page, call it z\textbf{z}z. Then the cross product is defined by the determinate computed computed from the components of the two vectors and projected along, namely,

A×B=∣AxAyBxBy∣z=(AxBy−AyBx)z     (3). \begin{aligned} \textbf{A} \times \textbf{B} &= \begin{vmatrix} A_{x} & A_{y} \\ B_{x} & B_{y} \end{vmatrix}\textbf{z} \\ &= \left( A_{x}B_{y} - A_{y} B_{x} \right)\textbf{z} \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (3). A×B​=∣∣∣∣​Ax​Bx​​Ay​By​​∣∣∣∣​z=(Ax​By​−Ay​Bx​)z​     (3).

Substituting equation (2)(2)(2) into (3)(3)(3) and making use of,

sin(θ+γ)=sinθ cosγ + cosθ sinγcos(θ+γ)=cosθ cosγ − sinθ sinγsin2γ + cos2γ=1 \begin{gathered} \sin{\left(\theta + \gamma\right)} = \sin{\theta}\ \cos{\gamma}\ +\ \cos{\theta}\ \sin{\gamma} \\ \cos{\left(\theta + \gamma\right)} = \cos{\theta}\ \cos{\gamma}\ -\ \sin{\theta}\ \sin{\gamma} \\ \sin^2{\gamma}\ +\ \cos^2{\gamma} = 1 \end{gathered} sin(θ+γ)=sinθ cosγ + cosθ sinγcos(θ+γ)=cosθ cosγ − sinθ sinγsin2γ + cos2γ=1​

results in,

∣A×B∣=∣A∣∣B∣sinθ, \mid \textbf{A} \times \textbf{B} \mid = \mid \textbf{A} \mid \mid \textbf{B} \mid \sin{\theta}, ∣A×B∣=∣A∣∣B∣sinθ,

which is the area of the parallelogram indicated by orange in the figure above. sinθsin\thetasinθ can be assumed positive since θ\thetaθ can always be chosen such that 0 ≤ θ ≤ π0\ \leq\ \theta\ \leq\ \pi0 ≤ θ ≤ π.

Bivariate Jacobian

Consider the following coordinate transformation,

x=x(u,v)y=y(u,v)     (4). \begin{aligned} x &= x(u,v) \\ y &= y(u,v) \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (4). xy​=x(u,v)=y(u,v)​     (4).

applied to the integral,

∫Af(x,y)dxdy, \int_{A} f(x, y) dxdy, ∫A​f(x,y)dxdy,

where AAA is an arbitrary area in (x,y)\left(\textit{x}, \textit{y}\right)(x,y) coordinates. The following figure shows how area elements transforms between the (u,v)\left(\textit{u}, \textit{v} \right)(u,v) and (x,y)\left(\textit{x}, \textit{y} \right)(x,y) coordinates when transformation (4)(4)(4) is applied. The left side of the figure shows the (u,v)\left(\textit{u}, \textit{v} \right)(u,v) Cartesian Coordinate System. In this system vertical lines of constant u\textit{u}u are colored orange and horizontal lines of constant v\textit{v}v blue. The right side of the figure shows the result of application of the transformation between the coordinate systems. The lines of constant u\textit{u}u and v\textit{v}v can be curved and not aligned with the (x,y)\left(\textit{x}, \textit{y}\right)(x,y) Cartesian coordinates as shown in the figure. The transformed (u,v)\left(\textit{u}, \textit{v} \right)(u,v) coordinates in this case are Curvilinear.

Consider the differential area elements indicated in the figure. In the (u,v)\left(\textit{u}, \textit{v} \right)(u,v) Cartesian coordinates the differential area element is given by dA=dudvdA=dudvdA=dudv but in the Curvilinear (x,y)\left(\textit{x}, \textit{y}\right)(x,y) the area element is distorted because the differentials defining the area are not orthogonal. In the infinitesimal limit it will become a parallelogram with area given by the cross product of dXd\textbf{X}dX and dYd\textbf{Y}dY which are tangent vectors to the curves of constant v\textit{v}v and u\textit{u}u respectively. To compute the cross product expressions for the differentials are required. From the transformation defined by equation (4)(4)(4) the components of the differentials are computed by assuming v\textit{v}v is constant for dXd\textbf{X}dX and u\textit{u}u is constant for dYd\textbf{Y}dY. It follows that,

dX=∂x∂udux+∂y∂uduydY=∂x∂vdvx+∂y∂vdvy    (5). \begin{aligned} d\textbf{X} &= \frac{\partial x}{\partial u}du\textbf{x} + \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}du\textbf{y} \\ d\textbf{Y} &= \frac{\partial x}{\partial v}dv\textbf{x} + \frac{\partial y}{\partial v}dv\textbf{y} \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ (5). dXdY​=∂u∂x​dux+∂u∂y​duy=∂v∂x​dvx+∂v∂y​dvy​    (5).

Now the cross product of the differentials above is given by,

dX×dY=∣∂x∂udu∂y∂udu∂x∂vdv∂y∂vdv∣z=∣∂x∂u∂y∂u∂x∂v∂y∂v∣dudvz=(∂x∂u∂y∂v−∂y∂u∂x∂v)dudvz. \begin{aligned} d\textbf{X} \times d\textbf{Y} &= \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial u}}\small{du} & \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial u}}\small{du} \\ \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial v}}\small{dv} & \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial v}}\small{dv} \end{vmatrix}\textbf{z} \\ &= \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial u}} & \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial u}} \\ \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial v}} & \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial v}} \end{vmatrix}dudv\textbf{z} \\ &= \left(\frac{\partial x}{\partial u}\frac{\partial y}{\partial v} - \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}\frac{\partial x}{\partial v} \right)dudv\textbf{z}. \end{aligned} dX×dY​=∣∣∣∣∣​∂u∂x​du∂v∂x​dv​∂u∂y​du∂v∂y​dv​∣∣∣∣∣​z=∣∣∣∣∣​∂u∂x​∂v∂x​​∂u∂y​∂v∂y​​∣∣∣∣∣​dudvz=(∂u∂x​∂v∂y​−∂u∂y​∂v∂x​)dudvz.​

The bivariate Jacobian is defined by,

∣J∣=∣∂(x,y)∂(u,v)∣=∣∂x∂u∂x∂v∂y∂u∂y∂v∣=(∂x∂u∂y∂v−∂y∂u∂x∂v). \begin{aligned} \mid J \mid &= \left| \frac{\partial\left(x, y\right)}{\partial\left(u, v\right)} \right| \\ &= \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial u}} & \frac{\small{\partial x}}{\small{\partial v}} \\ \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial u}} & \frac{\small{\partial y}}{\small{\partial v}} \end{vmatrix} \\ &= \left(\frac{\partial x}{\partial u}\frac{\partial y}{\partial v} - \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}\frac{\partial x}{\partial v} \right). \end{aligned} ∣J∣​=∣∣∣∣​∂(u,v)∂(x,y)​∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣​∂u∂x​∂u∂y​​∂v∂x​∂v∂y​​∣∣∣∣∣​=(∂u∂x​∂v∂y​−∂u∂y​∂v∂x​).​

In general the determinate of a matrix equals the determinate of the transpose of the matrix. It follows that the area element in (u,v)\left(\textit{u}, \textit{v} \right)(u,v) coordinates is given by,

dA=∣dX×dY∣=∣J∣dudv. dA = \mid d\textbf{X} \times d\textbf{Y} \mid = \mid J \mid dudv. dA=∣dX×dY∣=∣J∣dudv.

∣J∣\mid J \mid∣J∣ will scale the differential area dudvdudvdudv by the amount required by the transform in a manner similar to that seen for a single variable.

Finally the transform of the bivariate integral in equation (1)(1)(1) is given by,

∫Af(x,y)dxdy=∫A′f(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣J∣dudv, \int_{A} f(x, y) dxdy = \int_{A'} f(x(u,v), y(u, v)) \mid J \mid dudv, ∫A​f(x,y)dxdy=∫A′​f(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣J∣dudv,

where A′A'A′ is the region obtained by applying transform (4)(4)(4) to AAA.

Bivariate Normal Distribution

The Bivariate Normal Distribution with random variables UUU and VVV is obtained by applying the following linear transformation to two independent Normal(0,1)\textbf{Normal}(0, 1)Normal(0,1) random variables XXX and Y,Y,Y,

(U−μuV−μv)=(σu0σvγσv1−γ2)=(XY), \begin{pmatrix} U - \mu_{u} \\ V - \mu_{v} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{u} & 0 \\ \sigma_{v}\gamma & \sigma_{v}\sqrt{1 - \gamma^{2}} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} X \\ Y \end{pmatrix}, (U−μu​V−μv​​)=(σu​σv​γ​0σv​1−γ2​​)=(XY​),

where μu\mu_{u}μu​, μv\mu_{v}μv​, σu\sigma_{u}σu​, σv\sigma_{v}σv​ and γ\gammaγ are scalar constants named in anticipation of being the mean, standard deviation and correlation coefficient of the distribution.

An equation for XXX and YYY in terms UUU and VVV is obtained by inverting the transformation matrix,

(XY)=1σuσv1−γ2(σv1−γ20−σvγσu)(U−μuV−μv)    (6). \begin{pmatrix} X \\ Y \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v}\sqrt{1 - \gamma^2}} \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{v}\sqrt{1 - \gamma^{2}} & 0 \\ -\sigma_{v}\gamma & \sigma_{u} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} U - \mu_{u} \\ V - \mu_{v} \end{pmatrix}\ \ \ \ (6). (XY​)=σu​σv​1−γ2​1​(σv​1−γ2​−σv​γ​0σu​​)(U−μu​V−μv​​)    (6).

The distribution for XXX and YYY is found by making use of the assumption that they are independent Normal(0,1)\textbf{Normal}(0, 1)Normal(0,1), namely,

f(x,y)=12πe−(x2+y2)/2     (7). f(x,y) = \frac{1}{2\pi}e^{-(x^2 + y^2) / 2}\ \ \ \ \ (7). f(x,y)=2π1​e−(x2+y2)/2     (7).

In the previous section it was shown that if a transformation of the form,

x=x(u,v)y=y(u,v), \begin{aligned} x &= x(u, v) \\ y &= y(u, v), \end{aligned} xy​=x(u,v)=y(u,v),​

is available the transformed density is given by,

g(u,v)=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))     (8), g(u, v) = \mid J \mid f(x(u,v), y(u,v))\ \ \ \ \ (8), g(u,v)=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))     (8),

where ∣J∣\mid J \mid∣J∣ is the Jacobian,

∣J∣=∂x∂u∂y∂v−∂y∂u∂x∂v. \mid J \mid = \frac{\partial x}{\partial u}\frac{\partial y}{\partial v} - \frac{\partial y}{\partial u}\frac{\partial x}{\partial v}. ∣J∣=∂u∂x​∂v∂y​−∂u∂y​∂v∂x​.

The transformations x(u,v)x(u,v)x(u,v) and y(u,v)y(u,v)y(u,v) can be determined from equation (6)(6)(6),

x(u,v)=(u−μu)σuy(u,v)=11−γ2[1σv(v−μv)−γσu(u−μu)]     (9). \begin{aligned} x(u,v) & = \frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}{\sigma_{u}} \\ y(u,v) & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\gamma^2}} \left[ \frac{1}{\sigma_{v}}\left(v-\mu_{v}\right) - \frac{\gamma}{\sigma_{u}}\left(u-\mu_{u}\right) \right] \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (9). x(u,v)y(u,v)​=σu​(u−μu​)​=1−γ2​1​[σv​1​(v−μv​)−σu​γ​(u−μu​)]​     (9).

It follows that the Jacobian is given by,

∣J∣=1σuσv1−γ2     (10) \mid J \mid = \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}\ \ \ \ \ (10) ∣J∣=σu​σv​1−γ2​1​     (10)

With the goal of keeping things simple in the evaluation of equation (8)(8)(8) the exponential argument term of equation (7)(7)(7), x2+y2,x^2 + y^2,x2+y2, will first be considered. Now, making use of equations (9)(9)(9) gives,

x2+y2=x2(u,v)+y2(u,v)=(u−μu)2σu2+11−γ2[1σv(v−μv)−γσu(u−μu)]2=(u−μu)2σu2+γ21−γ2(u−μu)2σu2+11−γ2(v−μv)2σv2−2γ1−γ2(u−μu)(v−μv)σuσv=11−γ2[(u−μu)2σu2(1−γ2+γ2)(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]=11−γ2[(u−μu)2σu2+(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu],     (11) \begin{aligned} x^2 + y^2 &= x^2(u,v) + y^2(u,v) \\ &= \frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}{\sigma_{u}^2} + \frac{1}{1-\gamma^2}\left[\frac{1}{\sigma_{v}}\left(v-\mu_{v}\right) - \frac{\gamma}{\sigma_{u}}\left(u-\mu_{u}\right)\right]^2 \\ &= \frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}{\sigma_{u}^2} + \frac{\gamma^2}{1-\gamma^2}\frac{\left(u - \mu_u \right)^2}{\sigma_u^2} + \frac{1}{1-\gamma^2}\frac{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}{\sigma_v^2} - \frac{2\gamma}{1-\gamma^2}\frac{\left(u - \mu_u \right)\left(v-\mu_v\right)}{\sigma_u\sigma_v} \\ &= \frac{1}{1-\gamma^2} \left[ \frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}{\sigma_{u}^2}\left(1-\gamma^2+\gamma^2\right) \frac{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}{\sigma_{v}^2} - 2\gamma\frac{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}{\sigma_{v}}\frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}{\sigma_{u}} \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{1-\gamma^2} \left[ \frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}{\sigma_{u}^2} + \frac{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}{\sigma_v^2} - 2\gamma\frac{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}{\sigma_{v}}\frac{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}{\sigma_{u}} \right], \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (11) x2+y2​=x2(u,v)+y2(u,v)=σu2​(u−μu​)2​+1−γ21​[σv​1​(v−μv​)−σu​γ​(u−μu​)]2=σu2​(u−μu​)2​+1−γ2γ2​σu2​(u−μu​)2​+1−γ21​σv2​(v−μv​)2​−1−γ22γ​σu​σv​(u−μu​)(v−μv​)​=1−γ21​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​(1−γ2+γ2)σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]=1−γ21​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​+σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​],​     (11)

where the first step expands the right most squared term and the last two steps aggregate terms with the same posers of (u−μu)\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)(u−μu​) and (v−μv)\left(v-\mu_v\right)(v−μv​). Making use of equations (10)(10)(10) and (11)(11)(11) the Bivariate Normal Distribution PDF defined by equation (8)(8)(8) gives,

g(u,v)=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=12πσuσv1−γ2e−12(1−γ2)[(u−μu)2σu2+(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]     (12) \begin{aligned} g(u, v) &= \mid J \mid f(x(u,v), y(u,v)) \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} + \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (12) g(u,v)​=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​+σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]​     (12)

With this form of the Bivariate Normal Distribution PDF extensions to higher dimensions is not clear. In the next section a form us described that makes this clear.

Matrix Form of Bivariate Normal Distribution

A matrix form for the Bivariate Normal Distribution PDF can be constructed that scales to higher dimensions. Here the version for two variables is compared with the results of the previous section followed by a discussion of extension to an arbitrary number of dimensions. To begin consider the column vectors,

Y=(y1y2)μ=(μ1μ2)P=(σ12γσ1σ2γσ1σ2σ22)     (14) \begin{gathered} Y = \begin{pmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \end{pmatrix} \mu = \begin{pmatrix} \mu_1 \\ \mu_2 \end{pmatrix} \\ P = \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{1}^{2} & \gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} \\ \gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} & \sigma_{2}^{2} \end{pmatrix} \\ \end{gathered}\ \ \ \ \ (14) Y=(y1​y2​​)μ=(μ1​μ2​​)P=(σ12​γσ1​σ2​​γσ1​σ2​σ22​​)​     (14)

Here YYY is the column vector of Bivariate Normal Random variables, μ\muμ the column vector of mean values and PPP is called the covariance matrix. To continue the inverse of the covariance matrix and determinate are required. First, the inverse is given by,

P−1=1σ12σ22(1−γ2)(σ22−γσ1σ2−γσ1σ2σ12), P^{-1} = \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{2}^{2} & -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} \\ -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} & \sigma_{1}^{2} \end{pmatrix}, P−1=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​(σ22​−γσ1​σ2​​−γσ1​σ2​σ12​​),

and the determinate is,

∣P∣=σ12σ22(1−γ2) \mid P \mid = \sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right) ∣P∣=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)

Now consider the product where (Y−μ)T\left( Y - \mu\right)^{T}(Y−μ)T is the transpose of (Y−μ)\left( Y - \mu\right)(Y−μ),

(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ). \left( Y - \mu\right)^{T}P^{-1}\left(Y-\mu\right). (Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ).

The two rightmost terms evaluate to,

P−1(Y−μ)=1σ12σ22(1−γ2)(σ22−γσ1σ2−γσ1σ2σ12)(y1−μ1y2−μ2)=1σ12σ22(1−γ2)(σ22(y1−μ1)−γσ1σ2(y2−μ2)−γσ1σ2(y1−μ1)+σ12(y2−μ2)). \begin{aligned} P^{-1}\left(Y-\mu\right) &= \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{2}^{2} & -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} \\ -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2} & \sigma_{1}^{2} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} y_1 -\mu_1 \\ y_2 -\mu_2 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{2}^{2}\left(y_1 -\mu_1\right) - \gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_2 -\mu_2\right) \\ -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_1 -\mu_1\right) + \sigma_{1}^{2}\left(y_2 -\mu_2\right) \end{pmatrix}. \end{aligned} P−1(Y−μ)​=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​(σ22​−γσ1​σ2​​−γσ1​σ2​σ12​​)(y1​−μ1​y2​−μ2​​)=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​(σ22​(y1​−μ1​)−γσ1​σ2​(y2​−μ2​)−γσ1​σ2​(y1​−μ1​)+σ12​(y2​−μ2​)​).​

Continuing the evaluation by including the left most term gives,

(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)=1σ12σ22(1−γ2)(y1−μ1y2−μ2)(σ22(y1−μ1)−γσ1σ2(y2−μ2)−γσ1σ2(y1−μ1)+σ12(y2−μ2))=1σ12σ22(1−γ2){[σ22(y1−μ1)−γσ1σ2(y2−μ2)](y1−μ1)+[σ12(y2−μ2)−γσ1σ2(y1−μ1)](y2−μ2)}=1σ12σ22(1−γ2)[σ22(y1−μ1)2+σ12(y2−μ2)2−2γσ1σ2(y2−μ2)(y1−μ1)]=11−γ2[(y1−μ1)2σ12+(y2−μ2)2σ22−2γ(y1−μ1)σ1(y2−μ2)σ2], \begin{aligned} \left( Y - \mu\right)^{T}P^{-1}\left(Y-\mu\right) &= \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \begin{pmatrix} y_1 -\mu_1 & y_2 -\mu_2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{2}^{2}\left(y_1 -\mu_1\right) - \gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_2 -\mu_2\right) \\ -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_1 -\mu_1\right) + \sigma_{1}^{2}\left(y_2 -\mu_2\right) \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \left\{ \left[\sigma_{2}^{2}\left(y_1 -\mu_{1}\right) - \gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_{2} -\mu_{2}\right)\right] \left(y_{1}-\mu_{1} \right) + \left[\sigma_{1}^{2}\left(y_{2} -\mu_{2}\right) -\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_{1} -\mu_{1}\right)\right] \left(y_{2}-\mu_{2} \right) \right\} \\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2\left(1 - \gamma^2 \right)} \left[ \sigma_{2}^{2}\left(y_{1} -\mu_{1}\right)^{2} + \sigma_{1}^{2}\left(y_{2} -\mu_{2}\right)^{2} - 2\gamma\sigma_{1}\sigma_{2}\left(y_{2} -\mu_{2}\right)\left(y_{1}-\mu_{1} \right) \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{1-\gamma^2} \left[ \frac{\left(y_{1}-\mu_{1} \right)^2}{\sigma_{1}^2} + \frac{\left(y_{2}-\mu_{2}\right)^2}{\sigma_{2}^2} - 2\gamma\frac{\left(y_{1}-\mu_{1}\right)}{\sigma_{1}}\frac{\left(y_{2}-\mu_{2}\right)}{\sigma_{2}} \right], \end{aligned} (Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)​=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​(y1​−μ1​​y2​−μ2​​)(σ22​(y1​−μ1​)−γσ1​σ2​(y2​−μ2​)−γσ1​σ2​(y1​−μ1​)+σ12​(y2​−μ2​)​)=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​{[σ22​(y1​−μ1​)−γσ1​σ2​(y2​−μ2​)](y1​−μ1​)+[σ12​(y2​−μ2​)−γσ1​σ2​(y1​−μ1​)](y2​−μ2​)}=σ12​σ22​(1−γ2)1​[σ22​(y1​−μ1​)2+σ12​(y2​−μ2​)2−2γσ1​σ2​(y2​−μ2​)(y1​−μ1​)]=1−γ21​[σ12​(y1​−μ1​)2​+σ22​(y2​−μ2​)2​−2γσ1​(y1​−μ1​)​σ2​(y2​−μ2​)​],​

Which is the same as obtained using transform (9)(9)(9) in the previous section. Comparing the expression for ∣P∣\mid P\mid∣P∣ with equation (12)(12)(12) gives,

∣J∣=1∣P∣. \mid J \mid = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mid P \mid}}. ∣J∣=∣P∣​1​.

Putting these results together produces the desired result,

g(u,v)=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=12π∣P∣e[−12(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)]     (15) \begin{aligned} g(u, v) &= \mid J \mid f(x(u,v), y(u,v)) \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sqrt{\mid P \mid}} e^{ \left[-\frac{1}{2}\footnotesize{\left( Y - \mu\right)^{T}P^{-1}\left(Y-\mu\right)}\right] } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (15) g(u,v)​=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=2π∣P∣​1​e[−21​(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)]​     (15)

To extend to an arbitrary number of dimensions, nnn, the covariance matrix defined in equation (14)(14)(14) needs to written in a more general form,

Pij=Cov(Yi,Yj)     (16). P_{ij} = Cov(Y_{i}, Y_{j})\ \ \ \ \ (16). Pij​=Cov(Yi​,Yj​)     (16).

and the Multivariate Normal PDF becomes,

g(u,v)=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=1(2π)n/2∣P∣e[−12(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)]     (17) \begin{aligned} g(u, v) &= \mid J \mid f(x(u,v), y(u,v)) \\ &= \frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2}\sqrt{\mid P \mid}} e^{ \left[-\frac{1}{2}\footnotesize{\left( Y - \mu\right)^{T}P^{-1}\left(Y-\mu\right)}\right] } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (17) g(u,v)​=∣J∣f(x(u,v),y(u,v))=(2π)n/2∣P∣​1​e[−21​(Y−μ)TP−1(Y−μ)]​     (17)

To determine the linear transformation, analogous to equation (9)(9)(9), PijP_{ij}Pij​ is factored using Cholesky Decomposition.

In a following section it will be shown that for two variables,

Cov(Yi,Yj)={γσiσji ≠ jσi2i=j. Cov(Y_{i}, Y_{j}) = \begin{cases} \gamma\sigma_{i}\sigma_{j} & i\ \neq\ j \\ \sigma_{i}^{2} & i = j \end{cases}. Cov(Yi​,Yj​)={γσi​σj​σi2​​i ≠ ji=j​.

which is equivalent to equation (14)(14)(14).

Bivariate Normal Distribution Properties

Marginal Distributions

g(u)=∫−∞∞g(u,v)dvg(v)=∫−∞∞g(u,v)du \begin{aligned} g(u) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(u, v) dv \\ g(v) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(u, v) du \end{aligned} g(u)g(v)​=∫−∞∞​g(u,v)dv=∫−∞∞​g(u,v)du​

g(u)=∫−∞∞g(u,v)dv=12πσuσv1−γ2∫−∞∞e−12(1−γ2)[(u−μu)2σu2+(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]dv=12πσuσv1−γ2e−12(1−γ2)(u−μu)2σu2∫−∞∞e−12(1−γ2)[(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]dv=12πσuσv1−γ2e−12(1−γ2)(u−μu)2σu2∫−∞∞e−12(1−γ2){[(v−μv)σv−γ(u−μu)σu]2−γ2(u−μu)2σu2}dv=12πσuσv1−γ2e−12(1−γ2)(u−μu)2σu2eγ2(1−γ2)(u−μu)2σu2∫−∞∞e−12(1−γ2)[(v−μv)σv−γ(u−μu)σu]2dv=12πσuσv1−γ2e−(u−μu)22σu22πσv2(1−γ2)=12πσu2e−(u−μu)22σu2     (18) \begin{aligned} g(u) &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(u, v) dv \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} + \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] }dv\\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] }dv\\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left\{ \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}} - \gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right]^{2} -\gamma^{2}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_u\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_u^2}} \right\} }dv\\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} } e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} } \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}} - \gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right]^{2} }dv\\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{u}^2}} } \sqrt{\footnotesize{2\pi\sigma_{v}^{2}(1-\gamma^2)}}\\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{u}^{2}}}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{u}^2}} } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (18) g(u)​=∫−∞∞​g(u,v)dv=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​∫−∞∞​e−2(1−γ2)1​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​+σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]dv=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​σu2​(u−μu​)2​∫−∞∞​e−2(1−γ2)1​[σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]dv=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​σu2​(u−μu​)2​∫−∞∞​e−2(1−γ2)1​{[σv​(v−μv​)​−γσu​(u−μu​)​]2−γ2σu2​(u−μu​)2​}dv=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e−2(1−γ2)1​σu2​(u−μu​)2​e2(1−γ2)γ​σu2​(u−μu​)2​∫−∞∞​e2(1−γ2)−1​[σv​(v−μv​)​−γσu​(u−μu​)​]2dv=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e−2σu2​(u−μu​)2​2πσv2​(1−γ2)​=2πσu2​​1​e−2σu2​(u−μu​)2​​     (18)

g(v)=∫−∞∞g(u,v)du=12πσv2e−(v−μv)22σv2     (19) g(v) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(u, v) du = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{v}^{2}}}e^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{2\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}^2}} }\ \ \ \ \ (19) g(v)=∫−∞∞​g(u,v)du=2πσv2​​1​e−2σv2​(v−μv​)2​     (19)

Conditional Distribution, Conditional Expectation and Variance

g(u∣v)=g(u,v)g(v)g(v∣u)=g(u,v)g(u) \begin{aligned} g(u|v) &= \frac{g(u, v)}{g(v)} \\ g(v|u) &= \frac{g(u, v)}{g(u)} \end{aligned} g(u∣v)g(v∣u)​=g(v)g(u,v)​=g(u)g(u,v)​​

Using equations (12)(12)(12) and (19)(19)(19) gives,

g(u∣v)=g(u,v)g(v)=12πσuσv1−γ2e−12(1−γ2)[(u−μu)2σu2+(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]2πσv2e(v−μv)22σv2=1σu2π(1−γ2)e−12(1−γ2)[(u−μu)2σu2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]e{(v−μv)22σv2+12(1−γ2)[(v−μv)2σv2]}=1σu2π(1−γ2)e−12(1−γ2){1σu[u−(μu−γσuσv(v−μv))]2−γ2σv2σv2(v−μv))2}e{(v−μv)22σv2−12(1−γ2)[(v−μv)σv2]}=1σu2π(1−γ2)e−12(1−γ2){1σu[u−(μu−γσuσv(v−μv))]2}e{(v−μv)22σv2[1−1−γ21−γ2]}=1σu2π(1−γ2)e−12σu2(1−γ2){u−[μu−γσuσv(v−μv)]}2     (19) \begin{aligned} g(u|v) &= \frac{g(u, v)}{g(v)} \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} + \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] } \sqrt{2\pi\sigma_{v}^{2}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{v}^2}} }\\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sqrt{2\pi\left(1-\gamma^{2}\right)}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] } e^{ \left\{ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{v}^2}} + \frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} \right] \right\} }\\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sqrt{2\pi\left(1-\gamma^{2}\right)}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left\{ \frac{1}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \left[ u - \left(\mu_u - \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma\sigma_u}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v}} \left(\footnotesize{v-\mu_{v}}\right)\right) \right]^2 - \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma^2\sigma_v^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} \left(\footnotesize{v-\mu_{v}})\right)^2 \right\} } e^{ \left\{ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{v}^2}} - \frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} \right] \right\} }\\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sqrt{2\pi\left(1-\gamma^{2}\right)}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left\{ \frac{1}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \left[ u - \left(\mu_u - \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma\sigma_u}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v}} \left(\footnotesize{v-\mu_{v}}\right)\right) \right]^2 \right\} } e^{ \left\{ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_{v} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{v}^2}} \left[ \footnotesize{1} - \frac{\footnotesize{1-\gamma^2}}{\footnotesize{1-\gamma^2}} \right] \right\} }\\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_{u}\sqrt{2\pi\left(1-\gamma^{2}\right)}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{u}^{2}(1-\gamma^2)}} \left\{ u - \left[\mu_u - \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma\sigma_u}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v}} \left(\footnotesize{v-\mu_{v}}\right)\right] \right\}^2 } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (19) g(u∣v)​=g(v)g(u,v)​=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​+σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]2πσv2​​e2σv2​(v−μv​)2​=σu​2π(1−γ2)​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]e{2σv2​(v−μv​)2​+2(1−γ2)1​[σv2​(v−μv​)2​]}=σu​2π(1−γ2)​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​{σu​1​[u−(μu​−σv​γσu​​(v−μv​))]2−σv2​γ2σv2​​(v−μv​))2}e{2σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2(1−γ2)1​[σv2​(v−μv​)​]}=σu​2π(1−γ2)​1​e2(1−γ2)−1​{σu​1​[u−(μu​−σv​γσu​​(v−μv​))]2}e{2σv2​(v−μv​)2​[1−1−γ21−γ2​]}=σu​2π(1−γ2)​1​e2σu2​(1−γ2)−1​{u−[μu​−σv​γσu​​(v−μv​)]}2​     (19)

g(v∣u)=g(u,v)g(u)=1σv2π(1−γ2)e−12σu2(1−γ2){v−[μv−γσvσu(u−μu)]}2     (20) \begin{aligned} g(v|u) &= \frac{g(u, v)}{g(u)} \\ &= \frac{1}{\sigma_{v}\sqrt{2\pi\left(1-\gamma^{2}\right)}}e^{ \frac{\footnotesize{-1}}{\footnotesize{2\sigma_{u}^{2}(1-\gamma^2)}} \left\{ v - \left[\mu_v - \frac{\footnotesize{\gamma\sigma_v}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_u}} \left(\footnotesize{u-\mu_{u}}\right)\right] \right\}^2 } \end{aligned}\ \ \ \ \ (20) g(v∣u)​=g(u)g(u,v)​=σv​2π(1−γ2)​1​e2σu2​(1−γ2)−1​{v−[μv​−σu​γσv​​(u−μu​)]}2​     (20)

Correlation Coefficient

E[UV]=∫−∞∞∫−∞∞uvg(u,v)dvdu E[UV] = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} uv g(u,v) dvdu E[UV]=∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​uvg(u,v)dvdu

E[UV]=12πσuσv1−γ2∫−∞∞∫−∞∞uve−12(1−γ2)[(u−μu)2σu2+(v−μv)2σv2−2γ(v−μv)σv(u−μu)σu]dudv \begin{aligned} E[UV] &= \frac{1}{2\pi\sigma_{u}\sigma_{v} \sqrt{1-\gamma^{2}}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}uve^{ -\frac{\footnotesize{1}}{\footnotesize{2(1-\gamma^2)}} \left[ \frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}^2}} + \frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)^2}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_v^2}} - 2\gamma\frac{\footnotesize{\left(v-\mu_v\right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{v}}}\frac{\footnotesize{\left(u-\mu_{u} \right)}}{\footnotesize{\sigma_{u}}} \right] }dudv\\ \end{aligned} E[UV]​=2πσu​σv​1−γ2​1​∫−∞∞​∫−∞∞​uve−2(1−γ2)1​[σu2​(u−μu​)2​+σv2​(v−μv​)2​−2γσv​(v−μv​)​σu​(u−μu​)​]dudv​
